description: This course focuses on development of critical thinking skills to address health care problems of adults across the lifespan, with an emphasis on middle-aged and older adults, develop differential problem solving skills and determine appropriate management interventions. The management of common acute and chronic health conditions will include evidence based primary preventions, drug and treatment therapeutics, and referral to other health care providers. Students have the opportunity to build on previously acquired skills and to apply concepts of primary care to manage the health problems of adults across the lifespan.
name: PRIMARY CARE OF THE MIDDLE AGED AND OLDER ADULT

section.name: PRIMARY CARE OF THE MIDDLE AGED AND OLDER ADULT

values.comments:
This course focuses on primary care problems encountered by middle-aged and older people and their families in ambulatory and occupational settings. Students have the opportunity to build on previously acquired skills and to apply concepts of primary care to manage the complex health problems of middle-aged and older adults.
Very few students found this class particularly enjoyable because of the overload on assignments.  Some aspects of the work were informative, but the quality was overlooked due to the quantity.
Professor Bryan gave clear lectures, but lacked clarity when it came to major assignments.
The majority of students felt that the State of Science paper was difficult, tedious, and overwhelming.  Because of a lack of guidance, many students spent superfluous amounts of time dealing with formatting and rewriting, which sparked irritation.  They wished more time could have been dedicated to research.  Prerequisite: NURS 657.

This course focuses on primary care problems encountered by middle-aged and older people and their families in ambulatory and occupational settings. Students have the opportunity to build on previously acquired skills and to apply concepts of primary care to manage the complex health problems of middle-aged and older adults.

Students felt that the course went too quickly without making the proper amount of background information required to do the work.  However, largely the students felt the assignments were vaguely given and there was insufficient clarification given until the assignments were due.  

Many students praised Kiely’s initiative and ability to explain the material in an understandable way.  Also students felt that Kiely was “quick to encourage revisions” and was “refreshing” in her candor.

The majority of students felt that the “exams were fair and evaluated the course content well;” however, many also cited that there was a good deal of “busywork” involved in the course’s syllabus.  On the other hand, students celebrated “the tremendous amount of help” from Keily and her colleagues, and felt the material was “very applicable to practice.”
